title: Talinum fruticosum
text:
Talinum fruticosum is a <a href="Herbaceous%20plant">herbaceous</a> <a href="perennial%20plant">perennial plant</a> that is native to <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>, the <a href="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>, <a href="West%20Africa">West Africa</a>, <a href="Central%20America">Central America</a>, and much of <a href="South%20America">South America</a>. Common names include Ceylon spinach, waterleaf, cariru, Gbure, Surinam purslane, Philippine spinach, Florida spinach, potherb fameflower, Lagos bologi, sweetheart, and Kutu bataw in <a href="Ghana">Ghana</a> from the <a href="Akan%20language">Akan language</a> It is widely grown in tropical regions as a <a href="leaf%20vegetable">leaf vegetable</a>.
Description.
The plant grows erect, reaching a height of . It bears small, pink <a href="flower">flower</a>s and broad, fleshy <a href="leaf">leaves</a>.
Uses.
As a <a href="leaf%20vegetable">leaf vegetable</a>, "T. fruticosum" is rich in <a href="vitamin">vitamin</a>s, including <a href="vitamin%20A">vitamins A</a> and <a href="vitamin%20C">C</a>, and <a href="dietary%20mineral">minerals</a> such as <a href="iron">iron</a> and <a href="calcium">calcium</a>. Because it is high in <a href="oxalic%20acid">oxalic acid</a>, consumption should be avoided or limited by those suffering from <a href="kidney">kidney</a> disorders, <a href="gout">gout</a>, and <a href="rheumatoid%20arthritis">rheumatoid arthritis</a>. It is cultivated in <a href="West%20Africa">West Africa</a>, <a href="South%20Asia">South Asia</a>, <a href="Southeast%20Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, and the warmer parts of <a href="North%20America">North</a> and <a href="South%20America">South America</a>. Along with "<a href="Celosia">Celosia</a>" species, "T. fruticosum" is one of the most important leaf vegetables of <a href="Nigeria">Nigeria</a>. In <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a> it is grown along the banks of the <a href="Amazon%20River">Amazon River</a>, and is consumed mainly in the states of <a href="Par%C3%A1">Pará</a> and <a href="Amazonas%20State%2C%20Brazil">Amazonas</a>.
